title: 110_s152
content: The Act may be cited as the "Early Education Act of 2007". Congress finds that all children should have access to high quality early education as it is crucial for brain development and academic achievement. Research shows that early education programs improve reading and math skills compared to children who do not participate. Quality early education programs have been shown to improve academic performance in reading and math, reduce the need for special education services, enhance learning retention, creativity, and social skills, and increase enthusiasm for school. Studies indicate that investing in early education can result in significant cost savings later on. Title X of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 is amended to include an Early Education Program. Studies show that quality early education programs can improve academic performance, reduce the need for special education services, enhance learning retention, creativity, and social skills, and increase enthusiasm for school, leading to significant cost savings later on. The Early Education Program aims to provide half-day schooling each weekday before kindergarten to develop early literacy and numerical skills in young children. The Secretary can award grants to State educational agencies to expand education systems with early education programs, with a matching requirement not exceeding 50%. The Early Education Program provides half-day schooling before kindergarten to enhance early literacy and numerical skills in young children. Grants awarded to State educational agencies for program expansion must not exceed 50% of the total cost. Programs must be carried out by local educational agencies in public school buildings or other facilities, available to all children served by the agency, and involve qualified instructors. The State educational agency must submit an application for a grant under this section, detailing the program to be assisted, its purpose, total cost, and matching funds source. Instructors involved must be licensed or certified. The Secretary will establish a monitoring system to carry out the section's purpose. The Secretary shall establish a monitoring system for programs funded under this section and report annually to Congress. Funds must supplement, not supplant, other Federal, State, or local funds. $300,000,000 is authorized for each fiscal year from 2008 to 2012. The Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 is amended to include a new title for early education programs.
